Description: Pottery wine-jar of Nedjmet: a slender shouldered jar with matching lid. It was thrown in four sections, joined at the base of the neck, middle of the body and top of the foot. The exterior of the vessel and lid are covered with pink slip applied with a brush. Painted decoration in blue with dark red outlines comprises plain bands alternating with pendant leaf and lotus bands. There is a hieroglyphic inscription in black around shoulder, naming the lady Nedjnet.
Curator's comments: The lady Nejmet was well provided with wine for the next world. This vase belongs to a set of at least four, two containing Delta wine and two containing wine from the south. Wallis, in his catalogue of part of the Macgregor collection written in 1898, described these vases as 'the most important decorated Egyptian un-glazed vases yet discovered'. Vintage wines seem to have been the prerogative of the king - as this one of King Tutankhamun, 'Year 5. Sweet wine of the House of Aton of the Western River. Chief vintner Nakht' suggests. Detailed labels of this type are rare for wine destined for private persons. Bibliography: The British Museum, 'British Museum' Quarterly 5 (1930-1), p. 50, pl. xxii, b; Sotheby's sale catalogue, 26 June to 6 July 1922, no. 1733, pl. li, there incorrectly captioned '1736'; 'Ancient Egyptian Art' (Burlington Fine Arts Club, London, 1922), p. 64, pl. xxxv; H. Wallis, 'Egyptian ceramic art : the MacGregor collection : a contribution towards the history of Egyptian pottery' (London, 1898), p. 34, pl. xv; L. H. Lesko, 'King Tut's Wine Cellar '(Berkeley, 1977), p. 30. D. Antoine and M. Vandenbeusch, Egyptian mummies. Exploring ancient lives, Sydney 2016, p. 109.
Two other jars, seemingly from the same set, are now in the Penn Museum, E 14368 and E14369 See Silverman, Searching for Ancient Egypt, 1997, pp. 216-7
Bibliographic references: Bourriau 1981 / Umm el-Ga'ab: Pottery from the Nile Valley Before the Arab Conquest (242)
Shaw & Nicholson 1995 / British Museum Dictionary of Ancient Egypt (p23)
